If you ripped out the life system and made the collectibles actually collectible, this would be elevated to a pretty fun game I think.

Finally the bosses aren't great - generally just endurance and reaction tests.

Dodgy platformer port. Very ugly background graphics (although some animations are quite nice) to the point levels are hard to navigate. Very uninspiring gameplay. I really wasn't feeling it and got a game over.

This is a tie in game for a dodgy action film, which has been converted into a pretty bad Doom-style FPS.

Although the 3D FPS gameplay technically impressive for the GBA, it's ultimately inferior to Doom or Duke Nukem, both of which are struggling on the GBA. Combat is awkward, mainly due to the scarcity of ammo. Often the level design excerbates this by e.g. only giving you ammo for the godawful sniper rifle or the questionable grenades. 

It starts off ok but becomes kind of bullshit later in the game as levels are filled with very tough enemies while you are struggling for ammo for any of the weapons that are really effective against them. Ended up rage quitting quite late in the game on a level where you are forced to use the aforementioned terrible sniper rifle.

Levels try to introduce some variety but often end up being annoying. One level, for example, has the "rival agent" character following you around, unkillable, for the whole level, forcing you to attempt to sprint around mowing down enemies to reach the exit, while the awkward controls make life painful.

game: Tak and the Power of Juju
notes:
Reasonable platformer tie in with a 3d action/adventure game on home consoles. Technically fine if a little uninspired. Only real gripe is the birds that appear from nowhere flying  at your face as a reaction test.

Stopped playing due to losing a significant amount of progress. The game apparently autosaves (no manual saving) but not very frequently. Maybe you need to explicitly quit? In any case, it's not good enough for me to replay a whole world+.

Pretty decent 2d fighting game based on Dragon Ball Z. Very nice graphics and animations.

The gameplay isn't really my cup of tea, but it does seem to nicely capture the feel of Dragon Ball Z fights - you fly around punching and firing Ki blasts, and occaisionally someone crashes through a mountain. I never got the hang of the close combat punching, and it was hard to reliably trigger special moves due to the awkward button combo of R+A+B all at once.

Played through one story mode, Trunks', which seemed to be a modified version of the anime story placing Trunks at the fore.
Very generic platformer. Mildly interesting gadgets but they're quite clunky to use. My heart wasn't in it.

This stalled me out for way too long. I didn't enjoy this one, and it seemed worse than the other 2 DKC games for some reason. Many problems with lack of FOV. This one had really terrible Beehive levels with terrible "walljumping" off sticky walls, which broke me.

game: Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars
notes: Ok point and click adventure, which is somewhat unique for GBA. Some crazy logic in puzzles, animation was good although everything was too noisily pixelated. Not the best overall.
It's classic castlevania. Hard as nails, awkward platforming, obnoxious medusa heads. Don't have the patience for it so gave up quickly.
Much the same as the first one, slightly dodgy giant robot SRPG. Not the best with a bad interface. Gave up after a while.
Chu Chu Rocket is a nice puzzle game where you guide mice to their escape rockets while avoiding cats. I've played a fair bit of it including recently, so I just replayed normal puzzle mode.

game: SpongeBob SquarePants: Revenge of the Flying Dutchman
notes: Yet another dodgy tie in platformer. Mildly interesting mechanics with bubble blowing, but quite clunky controls. Lost interesting pretty fast.

game: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six: Rogue Spear
notes: Trying to cram way too much tactical shooter into too little console. Very dodgy control scheme which you can't really figure out by playing.
Somewhat decent platformer adaptation of stealth game. Got bored fairly quickly. I'm incredibly done with platformer tie ins.

Very solid turn based strategy for the GBA. Accessible but reasonably deep. Mainly let down by somewaht dodgy AI (which cheats on Fog-of-war maps). Got to the final campaign mission which is kind of massive slog against a big enemy starting army. Ended to avoid bogging down forever.

Not as bad as the score might make you think, but not great. Decent little platformer which feels a little like Sonic. Suffers from making the character too big so the screen feels way too small, and requires too much exploration in its gameplay.

Sabrewulf is a real hidden gem. A simple platformer where you cross a level to the right until you find a treasure outside the titular wulf's den, then run back to the beginning being chased. Short levels keep this formula from being too obnoxious.

What makes this game is the creature system. You accumulate and inventory of creatures you can place down in levels at any time, to do stuff like creating platforms, dropping bombs, or spawning a friendly creature to club enemies. The game allows really interesting emergent interactions between these creatures, enemies, and the environments, creating quite cool and unique gameplay possibilities. Have a creature kick a bomb over a gap to open up a wall. Place a platform to make an enemy bonk its head and fall into a pit. The possibilities are endless.

However, this system is kind of underused and you can often just platform or bruteforce your way through levels. I think it would benefit a lot from more puzzle style levels rather than straight platforming, requiring you to mess with the creature interactions.

The game has a ton of polish, with quite a fleshed out overworld to explore between platforming levels, with sidequests, minigames, and amusing dialog from NPCs. This is less surprising when you realise this game was made by Rare.

Overall I think Sabrewulf deserves more credit than its 75 score suggest. The game has flaws, like a very slow and easy start, and perhaps overstaying its welcome a little (with 8 worlds that become a bit of a slog later when the difficulty ramps up). But it's really one of the more unique and interesting games on the GBA.

A heroic attempt at porting a space shooter to GBA, but let down by the system's lack of power and controls. Surprisingly faithful in menus and such, combat is mostly flying around shooting at tiny dots and wrestling with the controls.

Solid enough Streets of Rage style beat-em-up. Short, but doesn't have enough going on to be any longer. Only annoying part was the final level which has enemies that can apparently stunlock you forever.
Classic RPG port. Badly localised with abbreviated names and some hard to understand progression with weird balance issues. Ended up killing to maintain challenge pace.
Arcade puzzle game where you place blocks to create rectangles which then disappear. Not the most amazing mechanic. Super weird theme about a Mr. Pants... OK but not spectacular.
Dodgy arcade motorbike racing with an emphasis on violence. Seemed weirdly hard, couldn't get past the first level. Not very motivated to try more.

game: Harvest Moon: More Friends of Mineral Town
notes: It's Harvest Moon, everyone's favourite farming simulator. The controls (not enough buttons really) and tiny inventory really hold this back. Good for the console, but couldn't bring myself to play much when Stardew Valley exists.
Puzzle platformer by Blizzard from before they made infinity dollars from WoW. Control vikings and solve fairly boring puzzles using their unique abilities. I wasn't super into this.

Replayed the bonus mode of both games, having played them in the challenge previously: Maxim mode of HoD and Julius mode of AoS.

Both are similar with you controlling an alternate character who starts fully powered up, and only need to wipe out the bosses before ending the game. Fun enough, difficulty was a little odd in both, Maxim was kinda-easy throughout and Julius starts pathetically easy but gets super challenging.

Lack of motivation to explore is the main flaw since most mechanics are blocked off for the bonus chars. Still good though.

For being such an amazing combo though, the pack as a whole gets 5/5.

Real hidden gem where you play a ninja policeman. Really good core gameplay with fun grappling hook swinging and decent fighting. Quite short and without too much to change up the gameplay though. Pretty fun.

game: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past
notes: Took me way too long due to life, but it's a classic, real good game. The final dungeon maybe toes over into too much and some things are very hard to figure out without a guide, but otherwise pretty great.
Hot garbage even for a kid's tie in platformer. You move sooo slow. Boring driving minigame. Got bored after a level that was surprisingly punishing because of enemy hitboxes.
Arcadey/combat racer, played from an isometric perspective. Doesn't work super well, didn't grab me.
Another racing game, top down this time. Played a bit but it's still not grabbing me.

A kinda-decent platformer. It's at least trying to be a good game, but it falls prey to many of the common GBA platformer flaws, and I'm still way too burnt out on mediocre platformers to give this too much play time.
Another fighting game. No move list or practice mode so I had no idea what was going on. Has a really rough 3D graphical style. Played a bit until I hit a wall.
Yet another fighter straight away. Has a practice and move list. Still not up to too much though.
Yet another Tony Hawk game. These still don't work on GBA compared to home console. Still ugly.

Follows the standard beatemup formula, but not the best executed version I've played on GBA. No block or dodge, or much depth to the combat mechanics as far as I can tell, just hit first to avoid getting stunlocked. Has lives and game over and continues, played until running out of continues.

game: Bruce Lee: Return of the Legend
notes: Surprisingly good action platformer, I had a lot of fun with this. Decent combat and fast pace due to good run speed. Let down a little by sometimes questionable platforming, bad looks, and forced stealth sections.
Straight sequel to Season of Ice. They added a map which makes the game so much better. Only falls over in bosses and towards the end with annoying moving platforms.
Two arcadey puzzle games. Seem fine enough, not really completable.
It's pinball... with a Sonic theme. Maybe someday I'll get into pinball, but today is not that day.
It's an arcade brick breaking puzzle game, with the twist that you control the ball and have to avoid skull blocks to not die. Slightly unique mechanic, but it's not actually that good.

I have a lot of nostalgia for this game, as the first GBA game I ever owned, and it should be good as a Castlevania game. However, it sucks, and is definitely the worst GBA Castlevania. 

The core controls are horrible, because you default to walking at a stupid slow pace and have to double tap the d-pad to run at a good speed. This hampers the game throughout. It's full of unfun design. Multiple different forms of enemies that freeze you in place. Enemies that make you unable to attack for a really long time, like a minute, on contact. Crappy bosses that are only hard due to a combination of constant random projectiles and the poor controls. Boring level design with big rooms filled with many copies of the same enemy over and over. A levelling system that will make you fall behind if you don't grind through all the enemies leaving you doing piddly damage to enemies and bosses. Hearts that don't get refilled at save points and you have to grind torches to refill them. DSS cards that are gained by pure RNG, without any indication of which enemies drop them.

I stalled for a long time as I didn't want to give up on this, but I didn't have a lot of fun. Sick music and good graphics though. Ultimately I got to the last phase of the last boss before realising it was too cheap to beat without grinding up a lot of levels.

Rayman Advance is a port of the original PS1 version. It's a really good port, looks and plays great for a GBA game, capturing the original pretty well. The only real porting flaw is the camera which feels tighter on Rayman and makes some levels and jumps harder than they should be. I have some nostalgia for PS1 Rayman, as I played it back in the day. I remembered it being really hard, but I actually found the difficulty to be pretty good. Challenging but not frustrating for the most part.

Rayman does a really great job of theming. The worlds are very distinct, and avoid falling into classic "Lava World, Ice World" platformer cliches. It even manages to use "ice physics" (actually sliding on metal instrument tubes in the music themed world) to create actually fun levels. It also avoids overstaying its welcome. New mechanics are developed nicely, but not dragged out too much. Every level has something unique going on and they don't really ever feel like filler. The level design does use a lot of "things suddenly appear", but this is slightly better than in some games due to hints that triggers exist, and a sound effect when something pops into existence. Secret hunting can still be baffling though. Nice graphics and pretty good music and sound.

Controls are good, very responsive and they do the job perfectly. You gain new abilities through the course of the game, and do have to backtrack to use them to find all the hidden cages (which are required to beat the game). Again though, as the levels aren't too long or repetetive this avoids being too much of a chore. The combat uses a unique and pretty fun boomerang fist mechanic. Bosses are generally fair and avoid falling into the boring cycle-based bosses a lot of platformers use.

Ultimately gave up rather than hunt down every cage to finish the game. Overall, one of the better GBA platformers I've played despite not finishing.

Although it has its flaws, Metroid Fusion is still an amazing game. The totally linear design and unskipable dialog is annoying, but everything else about  the game is great. Burned through this pretty fast.
Another JRPG with dodgy translation and interface. Didn't waste too much time on this one.
Yet another isometric extreme sports game with all the same problems. Stylish presentation, but otherwise dodgy. Graffiti controls that are badly converted analog stick motions are the standout here.

A pretty fun and cute platformer. Standard kirby stuff really (although I haven't played a ton of kirby). Interesting to see a platformer where the main character can just fly. Smooth controls and good powerups from absorbing enemies. Had a good bit of fun.

game: Mary-Kate and Ashley: Girls Night Out
notes: It's a bad tie-in rhythm game. Didn't seem to work super well. Not very interested.

Second and last Kirby game almost back to back. A bit of an improvement over the Nightmare in Dreamland, liked the more open exploration structure even if it's confusing at times. Final boss sequence was a bit excessive. Had fun over all.

I quite enjoyed this and consider it a hidden gem. Quite fun hack and slash RPG. Has a few issues around the economy which can break the flow of the game. Ended up stopping midway through as it was starting to get repetetive without too much changing.

game: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events
notes: Tie in platformer yet again. Not too bad, has light adventure puzzle elements. Still a bit meh though.
Yet another another extreme sports game. Similar to others. Didn't spend too long on it.
RNGesus why you do this to me.
Pretty good, but I think I like it less than the sequel. A lot more story which interferes with the nice gameplay loop. Better crafting system though. Ended up ditching to avoid stalling forever.
Millionth arcade collection. Not much to see here.
Really fun 2d platformer, as with the other one. I think it's better as it's not trying to outdo itself. Has a few rough patches with some jumps and the platform art, but mostly great.

game: Super Mario World: Super Mario Advance 2
notes: My favourite Mario game due to nostalgia. Pretty great.

game: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
notes: Not a platformer and surprisingly decent. Still not great though.

This is one that I've been excited to play and finally finish. Did enjoy it a lot, but it has some design issues and gets a bit silly  towards the end of the game. Final few boss fights would have been really frustrating without save states. Got through it though.
Arcadey puzzle game. Wasn't super impressed by the mechanics.

Another pokemon game, probably the best on the GBA overall. Had fun despite taking a long time over it. Rayquaza captured via master ball carried me fairly hard through the Elite 4, although my team was doing some work.
A dodgeball simulator. Not something that particularly interests me. I'm not very familiar with dodgeball but this seemed like a strange variant.

Took me way too long as it's a long JRPG I was determined never to give up on.

Shares many of the strengths of Golden Sun 1. Main criticisms are that the cutscenes can go on for too long and battles are a touch easy. Exploration and puzzles remain good.

Interesting that the plot ends up being a kind of "comedy of errors" where everyone is either trying to save the world or do what they think is right, and conflict comes from misunderstanding motives. The closest thing to a main villain is Alex, the only character acting for selfish reasons, and he never really takes center stage as a bad guy with his plot resolved in the epilogue.
A fairly typical scrolling space shooter. Don't have the patience to grind through to completion.
A fairly typical seriousish golf game. Might be the same engine as Mario Golf Advance or just very similar implementation. No main mode to complete here.

Pretty similar to MMBN1. They have addressed some of my complaints about the original, with persistent health, a lower limit on identical chips, and better dungeon layouts. Ultimately reuses a lot of content from 1 and I decided to put it down since it was not holding my attention.
It's another weird pinball adaptation. Not very interested.

A super weird arcade puzzle game. Or maybe it's a scrolling shooter? You shoot little coloured... things? potatos? at other ones on the road, matching colours to clear them. You only seem to need to match 2 identical ones. I see why this did not become the next tetris.

This is an odd one. A turn based strategy game, effectively a very small Total War game, set in medieval England. Battles are just numbers going down until one side wins. Kind of clunky, didn't really capture my interest.
Yet another tie in platformer. Moving on quickly.
Similar to other ZM games, nice platformer but sky-high difficulty and frustration, and I've played too many of them already.

game: Final Fantasy I & II: Dawn of Souls
notes: FF1: It's janky and very unbalanced (seemed to get very easier from about 1/3 mark). But a lot of the defining FF elements are already in place, and it doesn't drag itself out too long. Definitely need a guide though as the game does not really tell you where to go a lot of the time.

game: Ultimate Muscle: The Kinnikuman Legacy - The Path of the Superhero
notes: It’s a wrestling game based on a weird anime that I actually do remember a bit of from my youth. The game is alright although its systems are a bit strange and convoluted.
I'm not a fan of Bomberman as a single player game. Haven't got much time for this one.
Quite an ambitious RTS for the GBA. Very clunky controls. Difficulty all over the place, ended up putting it down about half way through.
It's a tie in platformer which is actually pretty good. Apart from the final level (annoying) and boss (grindy and boring) it was pretty good and I enjoyed it. Really nice web swinging stuff.
It's a monster truck racing game. It seems alright, classic bad GBA 3D graphics, very loose controls, not a ton going on reallly.
Well made platformer but I just don't like Sonic games that much. I find that they transition from fast and breezy to just obnoxious in later stages when they're actually trying to create difficulty.

game: Harvest Moon: Friends of Mineral Town
notes: It's almost exactly the same as the other Harvest Moon.
Another GBA title that's trying to do too much with too few buttons and too little graphics hardware. Trying to navigate and aim in 3D space with the 2D top down view + altimeter is very painful.

game: The Urbz: Sims in the City
notes: It's a spinoff of The Sims which is trying way too hard to be edgy and down with the kids. Has only gotten more hilarious with age. As a game, it's doing some light adventure gameplay with some systems like needs and relationships, along with some fairly uninspired minigames.
It's an arcade puzzle game. It's not tetris.

game: Frogger's Adventures: Temple of the Frog
notes: I considered persisting with Frogger but as with many GBA games they’ve put in a lives/game over system which just serves to make the game artificially longer. Fundamentally it’s not a particularly fun or interesting game, and beating it won’t be particularly hard but will involve occaisionally messing up and having to replay a whole level, which is just annoying.
It's another racer adaptation with eye bleeding graphics. Not much to do here.

Wow. Incredible hidden gem (hidden for me anyway). Core gameplay is a run-and-gun shooter somewhat like Metal Slug. Has amazing action set pieces with really varied gameplay, including unique uses of rotation. Great graphics with both nice pixel art and really good usage of the GBA's graphical capabilities to make special effects. I'm going to be honest, I played on easy which I think was the right decision as I had a light and fun run through the action. Even so, didn't seem excessively hard at any point and probably is also good on normal (and I could even imagine playing this a bunch and getting good at it). Has some replayability with difficulties, alternate character and score/time attack. Final stage includes a boss rush which is the same boss characters with new fights. It even gets that right!
My complaints about the first game return. First person shooters on the GBA need to basically play like Duke Nukem or Doom, otherwise they're just going to be unfun.

Pretty good. Isn't as much of a metroidvania as you might think (despite plot ripping off Fusion) as it's perfectly linear with no extra upgrades rewarding exploration. Outstays its welcome a bit. You have to collect so many keycards and press so many switches.

Although Advance Wars 2 is really good, I ended up putting it down. The problem is as the campaign goes on the battles become larger and more complex, and generally longer. I find I have the most fun on smaller battles that can be done in a short amount of time, rather than a long slog. These long battles usually end up lacking really strong tactics too and become "fight efficiently and churn out units to counter what the enemy is doing" until you win, rather than any interesting strategy.
It's a beat-em-up. Seems fine, this type of game rarely clicks with me.

This has kind of a special significance for the GBA challenge as it's the reason why I dropped the floor on game ratings down to 70 and have put up with so many bad platformers. Was it worth it? Not really... A unique core mechanic but some weird design choices and it doesn't have a ton of legs.

So since this isn't the first gen 3 game I've played for the challenge, this time I tried doing a solo pokemon run. Swampert proved to be a beast as his only weakness is grass and there's no grass gym leader/E4. Honestly the hardest fight was probably the rival in the early/midgame (before acquiring an ice move).
This is from the same stable as some of my favourite games like Mario Golf and Golden Sun. However, I just don't enjoy playing tennis against the AI that much. It gets repetetive pretty fast.
Another entry into the "extreme sports games that don't scale well onto GBA". Not much here.
My problem with this is the same as MMBN2 - it's very similar to MMBN1 which I did not enjoy enough to support 3 games of content.
A pretty generic jrpg which failed to grab me.
This is a beat-em-up. A bit of an odd one, I found the character art style very odd. Gameplay seemed a bit rough with enemies moving a lot faster than you can.

This is another odd one. It wants to be a run and gun platformer like Metal Slug, but fails to capture anything that makes that genre fun. Controls are stiff and awkward, your default gun is very bad and you don't get a ton of ammo for other guns. Gameplay is slowed down by awkward platforming and somewhat mazelike levels. Didn't enjoy it.
A really solid platformer with a novel drilling mechanic that gets fully explored. Well designed levels, all of which bring something new, doesn't outstay its welcome. Can't ask for much more.
How many Tony Hawk games is this now? At least this is the last one.

game: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
notes: A top down adventure. I found it kind of funny that you just press a to fire a generic magic bolt and the game describes it as being one of 5 different canonical HP spells based on context. Anyway, not up to too much.
I was surprised that this was actually kind of a jrpg. Not that good though.
Some neat Flash features, including slow-mo and a zoom-to-enemies button. Outside of that, kind of a mindless button bashy beat-em-up.
Interesting SRPG with a bunch of weird systems including using cards for turns, persistent health and items, only one attack per turn, etc. Doesn't quite land I think but an interesting game.
Infamously nintendo-hard action platformer. Requires near perfect play to progress as you can only take 2 hits before dying and health pickups seem to be rare. Not really for me.
Turns out I was wrong when I thought I'd played the last Tony Hawk's skateboarding game. Being a licensed tie-in did not improve this game.

Kind of a simple puzzle game. Pressing directions moves all the blocks in the level, match each colour into one big block. In general just completing each puzzle seems easy but it has some bonus objectives which would actually be challenging to acheive. Didn't end up sticking with it.

game: Zone of the Enders: The Fist of Mars
